'''Ace Books''' is the oldest active specialty [[publisher]] of [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] [[novel|novels]]. It was founded in 1952 by [[A. A. Wyn|Aaron A. Wyn]], and began as a genre publisher, starting with [[mystery fiction|mysteries]] and [[western (genre)|westerns]]. It soon branched out into other genres, publishing its first science fiction title in 1953; this was a successful innovation and within a few years the science fiction titles outnumbered both the mysteries and the westerns. Other genres also made an apppearance, including non-fiction, [[gothic]] novels, and [[romance novel|romances]].
Ace also became well known for the ''[[dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'' binding format used for most of its early books, although it did not originate the format. Most of Ace's early titles were published in this format, and Ace continued to issue books bound dos-à-dos until 1973, in many genres. These proved attractive to collectors, and some rare titles now command prices up to $1,000.
Ace, along with [[Ballantine Books]], was one of the leading sf paperback publishers for the first ten years of its existence. With the death of owner A. A. Wyn in 1967, however, Ace's fortunes began to decline. Two prominent editors, [[Donald A. Wollheim]] and [[Terry Carr]], left in 1971, and in 1972 Ace was sold to [[Grosset & Dunlap]]. Despite financial troubles, Ace had further successes, particularly with the various [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] series, for which Carr was the editor (on a freelance basis after 1971). Further mergers and acquisitions resulted in Ace becoming a part of [[Berkley Books]], and Ace is now a paperback [[imprint]] of [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]]. The editorial team at Ace also edits the [[Roc Books]] imprint, although the two imprints maintain a separate identity.<ref name=Morgan>{{cite web | url = http://www.sfcanada.ca/winter2005/johnmorganinterview.htm | title = SF Canada Article - "An Interview with Editor John Morgan" by Celu Amberstone| accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
==Company founding and the Ace Doubles concept==
[[Image:AceD-36ConanCover.jpg|thumb|200px|Ace Double D-36, [[Robert E. Howard]]'s ''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan]] the Conqueror''. The novel on the reverse side was [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Sword of Rhiannon''.]] Donald A. Wollheim was working at [[Avon (publishers)|Avon Books]] in 1952, but intensely disliked his job. While looking for other work, he tried to persuade A. A. Wyn to found a new paperback publishing company. Wyn was already a well-established publisher of books and [[pulp magazine]]s under the name [[A. A. Wyn's Magazine Publishers]].<ref name=Tuck_Wyn>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 2| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1978 | pages = 471|id=ISBN 0-911682-22-8}}</ref> His magazines included ''Ace Mystery'' and ''Ace Sports'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.philsp.com/data/data002.html | title = Magazine Data File | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> and it is perhaps from these titles that Ace Books would draw its name. Wyn liked Wollheim's idea but delayed for several months; meanwhile, Wollheim was applying for other jobs, including assistant [[editor]] at [[Pyramid Books]]. Pyramid mistakenly called Wyn's wife Rose for a reference, thinking Wollheim had worked for her. When Rose told her husband that Wollheim was applying for another job, Wyn made up his mind: he hired Wollheim immediately as an editor.<ref name=Knight130>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight | authorlink= Damon Knight|title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 130}}</ref>
The first book published by Ace was a pair of mysteries bound ''[[Dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'': [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'', backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo'', priced at 35 [[cent]]s, with serial number D-01. A ''dos-à-dos'' book has the two titles bound upside-down with respect to each other, so that there are two front covers and the two texts meet in the middle (sometimes with advertising pages in between). This format has been generally regarded as an innovation of Ace's; it was not, but Ace published hundreds of titles bound this way over the next twenty years, and became the best-known publisher of the format. Books by established authors were often bound with those by lesser-known writers, on the premise that this would help more-obscure authors gain popularity. The main drawback of the Doubles format was that the two books had to fit a fixed page length (usually totalling between 256 and 320 low-height pages), thus one or both novels would often be cut to fit. Despite the cover statement "Complete and Unabridged", books so-labeled were often cut significantly.<ref>{{cite book | last= Corrick| first= James A.| authorlink= James A. Corrick| title= Double Your Pleasure: the ACE SF Double| year= 1989 | publisher= Gryphon Books| location= New York| | pages= 11|id = ISBN 0-936071-13-3}}</ref>
The last Ace double in ''dos-à-dos'' format was [[Mack Reynolds]]' ''The Rival Rigelians'', bound with his ''Planetary Agent X'', released in September 1973. Although Ace later released volumes containing two novels, they were arranged conventionally rather than ''dos-à-dos''. It was not until 1978 that Ace finally stopped releasing Doubles. All told, Ace published nearly 650 Ace Doubles, more than 600 of which were in ''dos-à-dos'' format.
==1950s and 1960s: genre specialization==
[[Image:AceGenreGraph.png|thumb|400px|Books published by genre during Ace's first seventeen years. Science fiction overtook the other two main genres by the mid-1950s, and was by far the dominant genre published in the '60s.]] Ace's second title was a western (also ''dos-à-dos''): [[William Colt MacDonald]]'s ''Bad Man's Return'', bound with [[J. Edward Leithead]]'s ''Bloody Hoofs''. Mysteries and westerns alternated regularly for the first thirty titles, with a few books not in either genre, such as [[P. G. Wodehouse]]'s ''[[Quick Service]]'', bound with his ''[[The Code of the Woosters]]''. In 1953, [[A.E. van Vogt]]'s ''[[The World of Null-A]]'', bound with his ''The Universe Maker'', appeared; this was Ace's first science fiction (''sf'') title. Earlier in 1953, Ace had released [[Theodore S. Drachman]]'s ''Cry Plague!'', with a plot that could be regarded as sf, but the book it was bound with—[[Leslie Edgley]]'s ''The Judas Goat''—was not sf, so the van Vogt Double is generally regarded as Ace's first foray into science fiction. Another sf Ace Double followed later in 1953, and sf rapidly established itself, alongside westerns and mysteries, as an important part of Ace's business. By 1955, more sf titles were released each year than in either of the other two genres, and from 1961 onward, the sf titles outnumbered the mysteries and westerns combined.
Another first for Ace came immediately after the van Vogt Double: [[Dorothy Malone (writer)|Dorothy Malone]]'s ''Cookbook for Beginners'' was the first Ace book not in ''dos-à-dos'' format. Single novels began to appear frequently beginning in 1954, and were at first used primarily for books not in Ace's main three genres (though the occasional sf, mystery or western title did appear in single format). By the 1960s, however, this had changed, and the letter-series system apparently indicated the change: the F and M series singles were overwhelmingly science fiction, but singles in the original D/G/S series, and the K series singles, were mostly outside Ace's three genres.
By the late 1950s, Ace's output was approaching a hundred titles a year, still heavily dominated by the three main genres. Almost all the books were 35 cents, though some slim single volumes were 25 cents, and a handful were 50 cents. In the early '60s, rising costs finally forced an increase in the price of the books, and more and more books appeared at 40 cents, 45 cents and higher. A few fat volumes such as the 1967 paperback of [[Frank Herbert]]'s ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' were priced at 95 cents. Other genres began to make a much more frequent appearance: scores of "nurse romances" appeared, beginning in 1960 with [[Joan Sargent]]'s ''Cruise Nurse'' bound with ''Calling Dr. Merriman'' by [[Margaret Howe]]. By the end of the decade, perhaps 70 more such titles had appeared, along with gothic novels, self-improvement books, "strange but true" books, and many others.
===Leader in science fiction===
With [[Ballantine Books]], Ace was the dominant science fiction paperback publisher in the 1950s and '60s. Other publishers followed their lead, catering to the increasing audience for sf, but none matched the influence of either company.<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 977}}</ref>
Market dominance was not only reflected in numbers of books published—Ace published the first novels of several noted science fiction authors during this period. They include: * [[Philip K. Dick]]'s ''[[Solar Lottery]]'' (1955, D-103, bound with [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Big Jump''); * [[Gordon R. Dickson]]'s ''Alien from Arcturus'' (1956, D-139, bound with [[Nick Boddie Williams]]' ''The Atom Curtain''); * [[Samuel R. Delany]]'s ''The Jewels of Aptor'' (1962, F-173, bound with [[James White]]'s ''Second Ending''); * [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s ''[[Rocannon's World]]'' (1966, G-574, bound with [[Avram Davidson]]'s ''The Kar-Chee Reign''); * [[Roger Zelazny]]'s ''[[...And Call Me Conrad|This Immortal]]'' (1966, F-393); * [[R. A. Lafferty]]'s ''[[Past Master (novel)|Past Master]]'' (1968, H-54).
Ace published much early work of other prominent authors, including [[John Brunner (novelist)|John Brunner]], [[Thomas M. Disch]], and [[Robert Silverberg]].
==Mid-1960s to today== [[Image:AceRussChaosDiedCover.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Joanna Russ]]'s ''And Chaos Died'' (1970), from the first [[Ace Science Fiction Specials|Ace SF Special]] series. The cover is by [[Leo and Diane Dillon]].]]
In 1964, science fiction author [[Terry Carr]] joined the company, and, in 1968, he initiated the [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] line, publishing critically-acclaimed original novels by such authors as [[Alexei Panshin]], [[R. A. Lafferty]], [[Joanna Russ]] and [[Ursula Le Guin]]. During the mid-to-late 1960s, Ace also obtained licenses to publish original novels based on several popular television series of the day, most notably some two-dozen ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' volumes and a trilogy based on ''[[The Prisoner]]''.
Carr and Wollheim also co-edited an annual ''Year's Best Science Fiction'' [[anthology]] series; and Carr also edited ''Universe'', a well-received original anthology series. ''Universe'' was initially published by Ace, although when Carr left Ace Books in 1971 the series moved elsewhere.
<!-- ==''Lord of the Rings'' controversy --> In 1965, Wollheim discovered a [[copyright]] loophole in the American edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. The [[Houghton Mifflin]] edition had been bound using pages printed in the [[United Kingdom]] for the [[Allen & Unwin|George Allen & Unwin]] edition, and as a result, U.S. copyright law (at that time) did not protect the text. Exploiting this loophole, Ace Books published the first-ever paperback edition of Tolkien's work, featuring cover art and hand-drawn title pages by [[Jack Gaughan]]. After considerable controversy and the release of a competitive authorized (and more complete) edition by Ballantine Books, Ace agreed to pay royalties to Tolkien and let its still-popular edition go out of print.<ref>{{cite web | author=Reynolds, Pat| year=2004| title=The Lord of the Rings: The Tale of a Text | url=http://www.tolkiensociety.com/tolkien/tale.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{ME-ref|letters|especially #270, #273 and #277}}</ref>
Wyn died in 1967,<ref name=Tuck_Wyn /> and the company grew financially overextended, failing to pay its authors reliably. Without money to pay the signing bonus, Wollheim was unwilling to send signed contracts to authors. On at least one occasion, a book without a valid contract went to the printer, and Wollheim later found out that the author, who was owed $3,000 by Ace, was reduced to picking fruit for a living.<ref name=Knight176>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight |authorlink= Damon Knight| title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 176}}</ref>
Both Wollheim and Carr left Ace in 1971. Wollheim had made plans to launch a separate paperback house, and in cooperation with [[New American Library]],<ref name=Knight176 /> he proceeded to set up [[DAW Books]]. Carr became a freelance editor; both Carr and Wollheim went on to edit separate Year's Best volumes.
In 1972, Ace was acquired by [[Grosset & Dunlap]], and in 1982, Grosset & Dunlap was in turn acquired by [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]]. Ace was reputedly the only profitable element of the Grosset & Dunlap empire by this time.<ref name=chicon>{{cite web | author=Bloom, Jeremy| year=1999| title=Chicon 2000:Editor Guest of Honor: Jim Baen | work=An Interview with the Editor Guest of Honor, Jim Baen| url=http://www.chicon.org/gohs/baen.htm | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: History| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/history.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> Ace soon became the science fiction imprint of their parent company.<ref name=penguin-ace>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: Ace Books| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/adult/ace.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Grosset & Dunlap operated an imprint called Ace Charter Books, which published mystery fiction such as reprints of the ''[[Simon Templar|The Saint]]'' series by [[Leslie Charteris]].
Carr returned to Ace Books in 1984 as a [[freelancer|freelance]] editor,<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 199}}</ref> launching a new series of Ace Specials devoted entirely to first novels. This series was even more successful than the first: it included, in 1984 alone, [[William Gibson (novelist)|William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'', [[Kim Stanley Robinson]]'s ''[[Three Californias Trilogy|The Wild Shore]]'', [[Lucius Shepard]]'s ''Green Eyes'', and [[Michael Swanwick]]'s ''In the Drift''. All were first novels by authors now regarded as major figures in the sf genre.
Other prominent sf publishing figures who have worked at Ace include [[Tom Doherty]], who left to start [[Tor Books]], and [[Jim Baen]], who left to work at Tor and who eventually founded [[Baen Books]]. Writers who have worked at Ace include [[Frederik Pohl]], [[Ellen Kushner]], and [[Laura Anne Gilman]].
In 1996, [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]] acquired the Putnam Berkley Group, and has retained Ace as their sf imprint. Ace's 2006 list includes [[Julian May]], [[Patricia A. McKillip|Patricia McKillip]], and [[Sharon Shinn]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week February 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books02b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week March 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books03b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New in Paperback: April 2006 | url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/NewInPaperback04.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>, with books from writers such as [[Alastair Reynolds]], [[Charles Stross]], [[Jack McDevitt]] and [[Joe Haldeman]] planned for the remainder of the year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: Forthcoming Books| url=http://locusmag.com/ForthcomingBooks.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>

==Ace Books titles== Ace titles are frequently collected, both for their covers and for their affiliation with individual genres. Many individual titles are now highly sought after. Much of [[Philip K. Dick]]'s early work appeared in Ace editions, and is now difficult to find in good condition. Among the rarest Ace titles are: * [[William Burroughs]] (as William Lee) ''Junkie'' (1955, D-015, bound with Maurice Helbrand's ''Narcotic Agent'')<ref>Near-fine copy priced at $1,000 located in second-hand bookstore {{cite web | url = http://www.heritagebookshop.com/ | title = Heritage Book Shop, Inc. | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> * [[Harlan Ellison]] ''The Deadly Streets'' (1958, D-312)<ref>Fine copy priced at $349.95 located in second-hand bookstore Wild Hills Books, Florida, via {{cite web | url = http://www.alibris.com/ | title = Alibris | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
The doubles format in itself has proved particularly attractive to collectors, with specialist reference works created for both the mystery and sf books, listing only the doubles. Several of these works are listed at the end of the reference section below. The following articles provide lists of all the Ace titles, organized by genre and by format (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'' vs. normal format).

The following lists give the individual series titles, for all genres.

=== Serial numbers === Ace titles have had two main types of serial numbers: letter series, such as "D-31" and "H-77", and numeric, such as "10293" and "15697". The letters were used to indicate a price. The following is a list of series with their date ranges and prices.
* D-series—35¢, 1952 to 1965. * S-series—25¢, 1954 to 1958. * T-series—40¢. This series is listed in Tuck's Encyclopedia,<ref>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 3| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1982 | pages = 715|id=ISBN 0-911682-26-0}}</ref> but he gives no examples in his index and there are none cited in other bibliographic sources. This series may therefore not exist. * F-series—40¢, 1960 to 1967. * M-series—45¢, 1964 to 1966. * G-series—50¢, 1958 to 1960 (D/S/G series); 1964 to 1968 (later series). * K-series—50¢, 1959 to 1968. * H-series—60¢, 1965 or 1966 to 1968. * A-series—75¢, 1965 to 1968. * N-series—95¢, 1965 to 1968.
The first series of Ace books began in 1952 with D-01, a western in ''dos-à-dos'' format: [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'' backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo''. That series continued until D-599, [[Patricia Libby]]'s ''Winged Victory for Nurse Kerry'', but the series also included several G and S serial numbers, depending on the price. The D and S did not indicate "Double" (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'') or "Single"; there are D-series titles that are not ''dos-à-dos'', although none of the ''dos-à-dos'' titles have an S serial number.
Towards the end of this initial series, the F series began (at a new price), and thereafter there were always several different letter series in publication simultaneously. The D and S prefixes did not appear again after the first series, but the G prefix acquired its own series starting with G-501. Hence the eight earlier G-series titles can be considered part of a different series to the G-series proper. All series after the first kept independent numbering systems, starting at 1 or 101.
In January 1969, Ace switched to a numeric coding system. The code depended on the title of the book: specifically, on the first significant word in the title. For example, [[Tom Purdom]]'s ''The Barons of Behavior'' was published by Ace in about 1972 as serial number 04760. The first letter of "Barons" is "B", so the code assigned is fairly early in the numeric range 00000 to 99999. This procedure for assigning numeric codes was in use at Ace at least into the early 1990s, and may still be in use today. For Ace Doubles, one of the titles was selected and used to determine what serial number would be used. For example, 11560 is the Ace Double ''The Communipaths'' by [[Suzette Haden Elgin]], backed with [[Louis Trimble]]'s ''The Noblest Experiment in the Galaxy''. The serial number here is derived from ''The Communipaths''; a serial number derived from the Trimble would have been about 58000.
For the later numeric series titles, the number is also part of the [[ISBN]]. To form the ISBN (if it exists) for one of these books, one prefixes to the serial number "0" (representing the English language/US), and "441" (Ace's publisher number). The last digit can then be calculated with an ISBN check digit calculator. For example, [[Christopher Stasheff]]'s ''Escape Velocity'' has serial number 21599; the ISBN is 0-441-21599-8.

'''Ace Books''' is the oldest active specialty [[publisher]] of [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] [[novel|novels]]. The company was founded in 1952 by [[A. A. Wyn|Aaron A. Wyn]], and began as a genre publisher, starting with [[mystery fiction|mysteries]] and [[western (genre)|westerns]]. It soon branched out into other genres, publishing its first [[science fiction]] ("sf") title in 1953; this was a successful innovation, and within a few years, sf titles outnumbered both mysteries and westerns. Other genres also made an appearance, including non-fiction, [[gothic]] novels, and [[romance novel|romances]].
Ace became well known for the ''[[dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'' binding format used for most of its early books, although it did not originate the format. Most of Ace's early titles were published in this format, and Ace continued to issue books in many genres, bound ''dos-à-dos'', until 1973. Ace books have proven attractive to collectors, and some rare titles now command prices of up to $1,000.
Ace, along with [[Ballantine Books]], was one of the leading sf paperback publishers for its first ten years in business. With the death of owner A. A. Wyn in 1967, however, Ace's fortunes began to decline. Two prominent editors, [[Donald A. Wollheim]] and [[Terry Carr]], left in 1971, and in 1972 Ace was sold to [[Grosset & Dunlap]]. Despite financial troubles, Ace had further successes, particularly with the various [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] series, for which Carr was the editor. Further [[mergers and acquisitions]] resulted in Ace becoming a part of [[Berkley Books]], and Ace is now a paperback [[imprint]] of [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]]. The editorial team at Ace also edits the [[Roc Books]] imprint, although the two imprints maintain a separate identity.<ref name=Morgan>{{cite web | url = http://www.sfcanada.ca/winter2005/johnmorganinterview.htm | title = SF Canada Article - "An Interview with Editor John Morgan" by Celu Amberstone| accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
==Company founding and the Ace Doubles concept==
[[Image:AceD-36ConanCover.jpg|thumb|200px|Ace Double D-36, [[Robert E. Howard]]'s ''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan]] the Conqueror''. The novel on the reverse side was [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Sword of Rhiannon''.]] [[Editor]] [[Donald A. Wollheim]] was working at [[Avon (publishers)|Avon Books]] in 1952, but intensely disliked his job. While looking for other work, he tried to persuade [[A. A. Wyn]] to found a new paperback publishing company. Wyn was already a well-established publisher of books and [[pulp magazine]]s under the name [[A. A. Wyn's Magazine Publishers]].<ref name=Tuck_Wyn>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 2| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1978 | pages = 471|id=ISBN 0-911682-22-8}}</ref> His magazines included ''Ace Mystery'' and ''Ace Sports'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.philsp.com/data/data002.html | title = Magazine Data File | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> and it is perhaps from these titles that Ace Books would draw its name. Wyn liked Wollheim's idea but delayed for several months; meanwhile, Wollheim was applying for other jobs, including assistant editor at [[Pyramid Books]]. Pyramid mistakenly called Wyn's wife Rose for a reference, thinking Wollheim had worked for her. When Rose told her husband that Wollheim was applying for another job, Wyn made up his mind: he hired Wollheim immediately as an editor.<ref name=Knight130>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight | authorlink= Damon Knight|title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 130}}</ref>
The first book published by Ace was a pair of mysteries bound ''[[Dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'': [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'', backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo'', priced at 35 [[cent]]s, with serial number D-01. A ''dos-à-dos'' book has the two titles bound upside-down with respect to each other, so that there are two front covers and the two texts meet in the middle (sometimes with advertising pages in between). This format has been generally regarded as an innovation of Ace's; it was not, but Ace published hundreds of titles bound this way over the next twenty years, and became the best-known publisher of the format. Books by established authors were often bound with those by lesser-known writers, on the premise that this would help more-obscure authors gain popularity. The main drawback of the Doubles format was that the two books had to fit a fixed page length (usually totalling between 256 and 320 low-height pages), thus one or both novels would often be cut to fit. Despite the cover statement "Complete and Unabridged", books so-labeled were often cut significantly.<ref>{{cite book | last= Corrick| first= James A.| authorlink= James A. Corrick| title= Double Your Pleasure: the ACE SF Double| year= 1989 | publisher= Gryphon Books| location= New York| | pages= 11|id = ISBN 0-936071-13-3}}</ref>
The last Ace double in ''dos-à-dos'' format was [[Mack Reynolds]]' ''The Rival Rigelians'', bound with his ''Planetary Agent X'', released in September 1973. Although Ace later released volumes containing two novels, they were arranged conventionally rather than ''dos-à-dos''. It was not until 1978 that Ace finally stopped releasing Doubles. All told, Ace published nearly 650 Ace Doubles, more than 600 of which were in ''dos-à-dos'' format.
==1950s and 1960s: genre specialization==
[[Image:AceGenreGraph.png|thumb|400px|Books published by genre during Ace's first seventeen years. Science fiction overtook the other two main genres by the mid-1950s, and was by far the dominant genre published in the '60s.]] Ace's second title was a western (also ''dos-à-dos''): [[William Colt MacDonald]]'s ''Bad Man's Return'', bound with [[J. Edward Leithead]]'s ''Bloody Hoofs''. Mysteries and westerns alternated regularly for the first thirty titles, with a few books not in either genre, such as [[P. G. Wodehouse]]'s ''[[Quick Service]]'', bound with his ''[[The Code of the Woosters]]''. In 1953, [[A.E. van Vogt]]'s ''[[The World of Null-A]]'', bound with his ''The Universe Maker'', appeared; this was Ace's first science fiction title. Earlier in 1953, Ace had released [[Theodore S. Drachman]]'s ''Cry Plague!'', with a plot that could be regarded as sf, but the book it was bound with—[[Leslie Edgley]]'s ''The Judas Goat''—was not sf, so the van Vogt Double is generally regarded as Ace's first foray into science fiction. Another sf Ace Double followed later in 1953, and sf rapidly established itself, alongside westerns and mysteries, as an important part of Ace's business. By 1955, more sf titles were released each year than in either of the other two genres, and from 1961 onward, the sf titles outnumbered the mysteries and westerns combined.
Another first for Ace came immediately after the van Vogt Double: [[Dorothy Malone (writer)|Dorothy Malone]]'s ''Cookbook for Beginners'' was the first Ace book not in ''dos-à-dos'' format. Single novels began to appear frequently beginning in 1954, and were at first used primarily for books not in Ace's main three genres (though the occasional sf, mystery or western title did appear in single format). By the 1960s, however, this had changed, and the letter-series system apparently indicated the change: the F and M series singles were overwhelmingly science fiction, but singles in the original D/G/S series, and the K series singles, were mostly outside Ace's three genres.
By the late 1950s, Ace's output was approaching a hundred titles a year, still heavily dominated by the three main genres. Almost all the books were 35 cents, though some slim single volumes were 25 cents, and a handful were 50 cents. In the early '60s, rising costs finally forced an increase in the price of the books, and more and more books appeared at 40 cents, 45 cents and higher. A few fat volumes such as the 1967 paperback of [[Frank Herbert]]'s ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' were priced at 95 cents. Other genres began to make a much more frequent appearance: scores of "nurse romances" appeared, beginning in 1960 with [[Joan Sargent]]'s ''Cruise Nurse'' bound with ''Calling Dr. Merriman'' by [[Margaret Howe]]. By the end of the decade, perhaps 70 more such titles had appeared, along with gothic novels, self-improvement books, "strange but true" books, and many others.
===Leader in science fiction===
With [[Ballantine Books]], Ace was the dominant science fiction paperback publisher in the 1950s and '60s. Other publishers followed their lead, catering to the increasing audience for sf, but none matched the influence of either company.<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 977}}</ref>
Market dominance was not only reflected in numbers of books published—Ace published the first novels of several noted science fiction authors during this period. They include: * [[Philip K. Dick]]'s ''[[Solar Lottery]]'' (1955, D-103, bound with [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Big Jump''); * [[Gordon R. Dickson]]'s ''Alien from Arcturus'' (1956, D-139, bound with [[Nick Boddie Williams]]' ''The Atom Curtain''); * [[Samuel R. Delany]]'s ''The Jewels of Aptor'' (1962, F-173, bound with [[James White]]'s ''Second Ending''); * [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s ''[[Rocannon's World]]'' (1966, G-574, bound with [[Avram Davidson]]'s ''The Kar-Chee Reign''); * [[Roger Zelazny]]'s ''[[...And Call Me Conrad|This Immortal]]'' (1966, F-393); * [[R. A. Lafferty]]'s ''[[Past Master (novel)|Past Master]]'' (1968, H-54).
Ace published much early work of other prominent authors, including [[John Brunner (novelist)|John Brunner]], [[Thomas M. Disch]], and [[Robert Silverberg]].
==Mid-1960s to today== [[Image:AceRussChaosDiedCover.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Joanna Russ]]'s ''And Chaos Died'' (1970), from the first [[Ace Science Fiction Specials|Ace SF Special]] series. The cover is by [[Leo and Diane Dillon]].]]
In 1964, science fiction author [[Terry Carr]] joined the company, and, in 1968, he initiated the [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] line, publishing critically-acclaimed original novels by such authors as [[Alexei Panshin]], [[R. A. Lafferty]], [[Joanna Russ]] and [[Ursula Le Guin]]. During the mid-to-late 1960s, Ace also obtained licenses to publish original novels based on several popular television series of the day, most notably some two-dozen ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' volumes and a trilogy based on ''[[The Prisoner]]''.
Carr and Wollheim also co-edited an annual ''Year's Best Science Fiction'' [[anthology]] series; and Carr also edited ''Universe'', a well-received original anthology series. ''Universe'' was initially published by Ace, although when Carr left Ace Books in 1971 the series moved elsewhere.
<!-- ==''Lord of the Rings'' controversy --> In 1965, Wollheim discovered a [[copyright]] loophole in the American edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. The [[Houghton Mifflin]] edition had been bound using pages printed in the [[United Kingdom]] for the [[Allen & Unwin|George Allen & Unwin]] edition, and as a result, U.S. copyright law (at that time) did not protect the text. Exploiting this loophole, Ace Books published the first-ever paperback edition of Tolkien's work, featuring cover art and hand-drawn title pages by [[Jack Gaughan]]. After considerable controversy and the release of a competitive authorized (and more complete) edition by Ballantine Books, Ace agreed to pay royalties to Tolkien and let its still-popular edition go out of print.<ref>{{cite web | author=Reynolds, Pat| year=2004| title=The Lord of the Rings: The Tale of a Text | url=http://www.tolkiensociety.com/tolkien/tale.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{ME-ref|letters|especially #270, #273 and #277}}</ref>
Wyn died in 1967,<ref name=Tuck_Wyn /> and the company grew financially overextended, failing to pay its authors reliably. Without money to pay the signing bonus, Wollheim was unwilling to send signed contracts to authors. On at least one occasion, a book without a valid contract went to the printer, and Wollheim later found out that the author, who was owed $3,000 by Ace, was reduced to picking fruit for a living.<ref name=Knight176>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight |authorlink= Damon Knight| title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 176}}</ref>
Both Wollheim and Carr left Ace in 1971. Wollheim had made plans to launch a separate paperback house, and in cooperation with [[New American Library]],<ref name=Knight176 /> he proceeded to set up [[DAW Books]]. Carr became a freelance editor; both Carr and Wollheim went on to edit separate Year's Best volumes.
In 1972, Ace was acquired by [[Grosset & Dunlap]], and in 1982, Grosset & Dunlap was in turn acquired by [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]]. Ace was reputedly the only profitable element of the Grosset & Dunlap empire by this time.<ref name=chicon>{{cite web | author=Bloom, Jeremy| year=1999| title=Chicon 2000:Editor Guest of Honor: Jim Baen | work=An Interview with the Editor Guest of Honor, Jim Baen| url=http://www.chicon.org/gohs/baen.htm | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: History| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/history.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> Ace soon became the science fiction imprint of their parent company.<ref name=penguin-ace>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: Ace Books| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/adult/ace.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Grosset & Dunlap operated an imprint called Ace Charter Books, which published mystery fiction such as reprints of the ''[[Simon Templar|The Saint]]'' series by [[Leslie Charteris]].
Carr returned to Ace Books in 1984 as a [[freelancer|freelance]] editor,<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 199}}</ref> launching a new series of Ace Specials devoted entirely to first novels. This series was even more successful than the first: it included, in 1984 alone, [[William Gibson (novelist)|William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'', [[Kim Stanley Robinson]]'s ''[[Three Californias Trilogy|The Wild Shore]]'', [[Lucius Shepard]]'s ''Green Eyes'', and [[Michael Swanwick]]'s ''In the Drift''. All were first novels by authors now regarded as major figures in the sf genre.
Other prominent sf publishing figures who have worked at Ace include [[Tom Doherty]], who left to start [[Tor Books]], and [[Jim Baen]], who left to work at Tor and who eventually founded [[Baen Books]]. Writers who have worked at Ace include [[Frederik Pohl]], [[Ellen Kushner]], and [[Laura Anne Gilman]].
In 1996, [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]] acquired the Putnam Berkley Group, and has retained Ace as their sf imprint. Ace's 2006 list includes [[Julian May]], [[Patricia A. McKillip|Patricia McKillip]], and [[Sharon Shinn]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week February 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books02b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week March 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books03b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New in Paperback: April 2006 | url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/NewInPaperback04.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>, with books from writers such as [[Alastair Reynolds]], [[Charles Stross]], [[Jack McDevitt]] and [[Joe Haldeman]] planned for the remainder of the year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: Forthcoming Books| url=http://locusmag.com/ForthcomingBooks.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>

==Ace Books titles== Ace titles are frequently collected, both for their covers and for their affiliation with individual genres. Many individual titles are now highly sought after. Much of [[Philip K. Dick]]'s early work appeared in Ace editions, and is now difficult to find in good condition. Among the rarest Ace titles are: * [[William Burroughs]] (as William Lee) ''Junkie'' (1955, D-015, bound with Maurice Helbrand's ''Narcotic Agent'')<ref>Near-fine copy priced at $1,000 located in second-hand bookstore {{cite web | url = http://www.heritagebookshop.com/ | title = Heritage Book Shop, Inc. | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> * [[Harlan Ellison]] ''The Deadly Streets'' (1958, D-312)<ref>Fine copy priced at $349.95 located in second-hand bookstore Wild Hills Books, Florida, via {{cite web | url = http://www.alibris.com/ | title = Alibris | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
The doubles format in itself has proved particularly attractive to collectors, with specialist reference works created for both the mystery and sf books, listing only the doubles. Several of these works are listed at the end of the reference section below. The following articles provide lists of all the Ace titles, organized by genre and by format (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'' vs. normal format).

=== Serial numbers === Ace titles have had two main types of serial numbers: letter series, such as "D-31" and "H-77", and numeric, such as "10293" and "15697". The letters were used to indicate a price. The following is a list of series with their date ranges and prices.
* D-series—35¢, 1952 to 1965. * S-series—25¢, 1954 to 1958. * T-series—40¢. This series is listed in Tuck's Encyclopedia,<ref>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 3| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1982 | pages = 715|id=ISBN 0-911682-26-0}}</ref> but he gives no examples in his index and there are none cited in other bibliographic sources. This series may therefore not exist. * F-series—40¢, 1960 to 1967. * M-series—45¢, 1964 to 1966. * G-series—50¢, 1958 to 1960 (D/S/G series); 1964 to 1968 (later series). * K-series—50¢, 1959 to 1968. * H-series—60¢, 1965 or 1966 to 1968. * A-series—75¢, 1965 to 1968. * N-series—95¢, 1965 to 1968.
The first series of Ace books began in 1952 with D-01, a western in ''dos-à-dos'' format: [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'' backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo''. That series continued until D-599, [[Patricia Libby]]'s ''Winged Victory for Nurse Kerry'', but the series also included several G and S serial numbers, depending on the price. The D and S did not indicate "Double" (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'') or "Single"; there are D-series titles that are not ''dos-à-dos'', although none of the ''dos-à-dos'' titles have an S serial number.
Towards the end of this initial series, the F series began (at a new price), and thereafter there were always several different letter series in publication simultaneously. The D and S prefixes did not appear again after the first series, but the G prefix acquired its own series starting with G-501. Hence the eight earlier G-series titles can be considered part of a different series to the G-series proper. All series after the first kept independent numbering systems, starting at 1 or 101.
In January 1969, Ace switched to a numeric coding system. The code depended on the title of the book: specifically, on the first significant word in the title. For example, [[Tom Purdom]]'s ''The Barons of Behavior'' was published by Ace in about 1972 as serial number 04760. The first letter of "Barons" is "B", so the code assigned is fairly early in the numeric range 00000 to 99999. This procedure for assigning numeric codes was in use at Ace at least into the early 1990s, and may still be in use today. For Ace Doubles, one of the titles was selected and used to determine what serial number would be used. For example, 11560 is the Ace Double ''The Communipaths'' by [[Suzette Haden Elgin]], backed with [[Louis Trimble]]'s ''The Noblest Experiment in the Galaxy''. The serial number here is derived from ''The Communipaths''; a serial number derived from the Trimble would have been about 58000.
For the later numeric series titles, the number is also part of the [[ISBN]]. To form the ISBN (if it exists) for one of these books, one prefixes to the serial number "0" (representing the English language/US), and "441" (Ace's publisher number). The last digit can then be calculated with an ISBN check digit calculator. For example, [[Christopher Stasheff]]'s ''Escape Velocity'' has serial number 21599; the ISBN is 0-441-21599-8.

'''Ace Books''' is the oldest active specialty [[publisher]] of [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] [[novel|novels]]. The company was founded in 1952 by [[A. A. Wyn|Aaron A. Wyn]], and began as a genre publisher, starting with [[mystery fiction|mysteries]] and [[western (genre)|westerns]]. It soon branched out into other genres, publishing its first science fiction ("sf") title in 1953; this was a successful innovation, and within a few years, sf titles outnumbered both mysteries and westerns. Other genres also made an appearance, including non-fiction, [[gothic]] novels, and [[romance novel|romances]].
Ace became well known for the ''[[dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'' binding format used for most of its early books, although it did not originate the format. Most of Ace's early titles were published in this format, and Ace continued to issue books in many genres, bound ''dos-à-dos'', until 1973. Ace books have proven attractive to collectors, and some rare titles now command prices of up to $1,000.
Ace, along with [[Ballantine Books]], was one of the leading sf paperback publishers for its first ten years in business. With the death of owner A. A. Wyn in 1967, however, Ace's fortunes began to decline. Two prominent editors, [[Donald A. Wollheim]] and [[Terry Carr]], left in 1971, and in 1972 Ace was sold to [[Grosset & Dunlap]]. Despite financial troubles, Ace had further successes, particularly with the various [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] series, for which Carr was the editor. Further [[mergers and acquisitions]] resulted in Ace becoming a part of [[Berkley Books]], and Ace is now a paperback [[imprint]] of [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]]. The editorial team at Ace also edits the [[Roc Books]] imprint, although the two imprints maintain a separate identity.<ref name=Morgan>{{cite web | url = http://www.sfcanada.ca/winter2005/johnmorganinterview.htm | title = SF Canada Article - "An Interview with Editor John Morgan" by Celu Amberstone| accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
==Company founding and the Ace Doubles concept==
[[Image:AceD-36ConanCover.jpg|thumb|200px|Ace Double D-36, [[Robert E. Howard]]'s ''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan]] the Conqueror''. The novel on the reverse side was [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Sword of Rhiannon''.]] [[Editor]] [[Donald A. Wollheim]] was working at [[Avon (publishers)|Avon Books]] in 1952, but intensely disliked his job. While looking for other work, he tried to persuade [[A. A. Wyn]] to found a new paperback publishing company. Wyn was already a well-established publisher of books and [[pulp magazine]]s under the name [[A. A. Wyn's Magazine Publishers]].<ref name=Tuck_Wyn>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 2| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1978 | pages = 471|id=ISBN 0-911682-22-8}}</ref> His magazines included ''Ace Mystery'' and ''Ace Sports'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.philsp.com/data/data002.html | title = Magazine Data File | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> and it is perhaps from these titles that Ace Books would draw its name. Wyn liked Wollheim's idea but delayed for several months; meanwhile, Wollheim was applying for other jobs, including assistant editor at [[Pyramid Books]]. Pyramid mistakenly called Wyn's wife Rose for a reference, thinking Wollheim had worked for her. When Rose told her husband that Wollheim was applying for another job, Wyn made up his mind: he hired Wollheim immediately as an editor.<ref name=Knight130>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight | authorlink= Damon Knight|title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 130}}</ref>
The first book published by Ace was a pair of mysteries bound ''[[Dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'': [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'', backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo'', priced at 35 [[cent]]s, with serial number D-01. A ''dos-à-dos'' book has the two titles bound upside-down with respect to each other, so that there are two front covers and the two texts meet in the middle (sometimes with advertising pages in between). This format has been generally regarded as an innovation of Ace's; it was not, but Ace published hundreds of titles bound this way over the next twenty years, and became the best-known publisher of the format. Books by established authors were often bound with those by lesser-known writers, on the premise that this would help more-obscure authors gain popularity. The main drawback of the Doubles format was that the two books had to fit a fixed page length (usually totalling between 256 and 320 low-height pages), thus one or both novels would often be cut to fit. Despite the cover statement "Complete and Unabridged", books so-labeled were often cut significantly.<ref>{{cite book | last= Corrick| first= James A.| authorlink= James A. Corrick| title= Double Your Pleasure: the ACE SF Double| year= 1989 | publisher= Gryphon Books| location= New York| | pages= 11|id = ISBN 0-936071-13-3}}</ref>
The last Ace double in ''dos-à-dos'' format was [[Mack Reynolds]]' ''The Rival Rigelians'', bound with his ''Planetary Agent X'', released in September 1973. Although Ace later released volumes containing two novels, they were arranged conventionally rather than ''dos-à-dos''. It was not until 1978 that Ace finally stopped releasing Doubles. All told, Ace published nearly 650 Ace Doubles, more than 600 of which were in ''dos-à-dos'' format.
==1950s and 1960s: genre specialization==
[[Image:AceGenreGraph.png|thumb|400px|Books published by genre during Ace's first seventeen years. Science fiction overtook the other two main genres by the mid-1950s, and was by far the dominant genre published in the '60s.]] Ace's second title was a western (also ''dos-à-dos''): [[William Colt MacDonald]]'s ''Bad Man's Return'', bound with [[J. Edward Leithead]]'s ''Bloody Hoofs''. Mysteries and westerns alternated regularly for the first thirty titles, with a few books not in either genre, such as [[P. G. Wodehouse]]'s ''[[Quick Service]]'', bound with his ''[[The Code of the Woosters]]''. In 1953, [[A.E. van Vogt]]'s ''[[The World of Null-A]]'', bound with his ''The Universe Maker'', appeared; this was Ace's first science fiction title. Earlier in 1953, Ace had released [[Theodore S. Drachman]]'s ''Cry Plague!'', with a plot that could be regarded as sf, but the book it was bound with—[[Leslie Edgley]]'s ''The Judas Goat''—was not sf, so the van Vogt Double is generally regarded as Ace's first foray into science fiction. Another sf Ace Double followed later in 1953, and sf rapidly established itself, alongside westerns and mysteries, as an important part of Ace's business. By 1955, more sf titles were released each year than in either of the other two genres, and from 1961 onward, the sf titles outnumbered the mysteries and westerns combined.
Another first for Ace came immediately after the van Vogt Double: [[Dorothy Malone (writer)|Dorothy Malone]]'s ''Cookbook for Beginners'' was the first Ace book not in ''dos-à-dos'' format. Single novels began to appear frequently beginning in 1954, and were at first used primarily for books not in Ace's main three genres (though the occasional sf, mystery or western title did appear in single format). By the 1960s, however, this had changed, and the letter-series system apparently indicated the change: the F and M series singles were overwhelmingly science fiction, but singles in the original D/G/S series, and the K series singles, were mostly outside Ace's three genres.
By the late 1950s, Ace's output was approaching a hundred titles a year, still heavily dominated by the three main genres. Almost all the books were 35 cents, though some slim single volumes were 25 cents, and a handful were 50 cents. In the early '60s, rising costs finally forced an increase in the price of the books, and more and more books appeared at 40 cents, 45 cents and higher. A few fat volumes such as the 1967 paperback of [[Frank Herbert]]'s ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' were priced at 95 cents. Other genres began to make a much more frequent appearance: scores of "nurse romances" appeared, beginning in 1960 with [[Joan Sargent]]'s ''Cruise Nurse'' bound with ''Calling Dr. Merriman'' by [[Margaret Howe]]. By the end of the decade, perhaps 70 more such titles had appeared, along with gothic novels, self-improvement books, "strange but true" books, and many others.
===Leader in science fiction===
With [[Ballantine Books]], Ace was the dominant science fiction paperback publisher in the 1950s and '60s. Other publishers followed their lead, catering to the increasing audience for sf, but none matched the influence of either company.<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 977}}</ref>
Market dominance was not only reflected in numbers of books published—Ace published the first novels of several noted science fiction authors during this period. They include: * [[Philip K. Dick]]'s ''[[Solar Lottery]]'' (1955, D-103, bound with [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Big Jump''); * [[Gordon R. Dickson]]'s ''Alien from Arcturus'' (1956, D-139, bound with [[Nick Boddie Williams]]' ''The Atom Curtain''); * [[Samuel R. Delany]]'s ''The Jewels of Aptor'' (1962, F-173, bound with [[James White]]'s ''Second Ending''); * [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s ''[[Rocannon's World]]'' (1966, G-574, bound with [[Avram Davidson]]'s ''The Kar-Chee Reign''); * [[Roger Zelazny]]'s ''[[...And Call Me Conrad|This Immortal]]'' (1966, F-393); * [[R. A. Lafferty]]'s ''[[Past Master (novel)|Past Master]]'' (1968, H-54).
Ace published much early work of other prominent authors, including [[John Brunner (novelist)|John Brunner]], [[Thomas M. Disch]], and [[Robert Silverberg]].
==Mid-1960s to today== [[Image:AceRussChaosDiedCover.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Joanna Russ]]'s ''And Chaos Died'' (1970), from the first [[Ace Science Fiction Specials|Ace SF Special]] series. The cover is by [[Leo and Diane Dillon]].]]
In 1964, science fiction author [[Terry Carr]] joined the company, and, in 1968, he initiated the [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] line, publishing critically-acclaimed original novels by such authors as [[Alexei Panshin]], [[R. A. Lafferty]], [[Joanna Russ]] and [[Ursula Le Guin]]. During the mid-to-late 1960s, Ace also obtained licenses to publish original novels based on several popular television series of the day, most notably some two-dozen ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' volumes and a trilogy based on ''[[The Prisoner]]''.
Carr and Wollheim also co-edited an annual ''Year's Best Science Fiction'' [[anthology]] series; and Carr also edited ''Universe'', a well-received original anthology series. ''Universe'' was initially published by Ace, although when Carr left Ace Books in 1971 the series moved elsewhere.
<!-- ==''Lord of the Rings'' controversy --> In 1965, Wollheim discovered a [[copyright]] loophole in the American edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. The [[Houghton Mifflin]] edition had been bound using pages printed in the [[United Kingdom]] for the [[Allen & Unwin|George Allen & Unwin]] edition, and as a result, U.S. copyright law (at that time) did not protect the text. Exploiting this loophole, Ace Books published the first-ever paperback edition of Tolkien's work, featuring cover art and hand-drawn title pages by [[Jack Gaughan]]. After considerable controversy and the release of a competitive authorized (and more complete) edition by Ballantine Books, Ace agreed to pay royalties to Tolkien and let its still-popular edition go out of print.<ref>{{cite web | author=Reynolds, Pat| year=2004| title=The Lord of the Rings: The Tale of a Text | url=http://www.tolkiensociety.com/tolkien/tale.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{ME-ref|letters|especially #270, #273 and #277}}</ref>
Wyn died in 1967,<ref name=Tuck_Wyn /> and the company grew financially overextended, failing to pay its authors reliably. Without money to pay the signing bonus, Wollheim was unwilling to send signed contracts to authors. On at least one occasion, a book without a valid contract went to the printer, and Wollheim later found out that the author, who was owed $3,000 by Ace, was reduced to picking fruit for a living.<ref name=Knight176>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight |authorlink= Damon Knight| title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 176}}</ref>
Both Wollheim and Carr left Ace in 1971. Wollheim had made plans to launch a separate paperback house, and in cooperation with [[New American Library]],<ref name=Knight176 /> he proceeded to set up [[DAW Books]]. Carr became a freelance editor; both Carr and Wollheim went on to edit separate Year's Best volumes.
In 1972, Ace was acquired by [[Grosset & Dunlap]], and in 1982, Grosset & Dunlap was in turn acquired by [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]]. Ace was reputedly the only profitable element of the Grosset & Dunlap empire by this time.<ref name=chicon>{{cite web | author=Bloom, Jeremy| year=1999| title=Chicon 2000:Editor Guest of Honor: Jim Baen | work=An Interview with the Editor Guest of Honor, Jim Baen| url=http://www.chicon.org/gohs/baen.htm | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: History| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/history.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> Ace soon became the science fiction imprint of their parent company.<ref name=penguin-ace>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: Ace Books| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/adult/ace.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Grosset & Dunlap operated an imprint called Ace Charter Books, which published mystery fiction such as reprints of the ''[[Simon Templar|The Saint]]'' series by [[Leslie Charteris]].
Carr returned to Ace Books in 1984 as a [[freelancer|freelance]] editor,<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 199}}</ref> launching a new series of Ace Specials devoted entirely to first novels. This series was even more successful than the first: it included, in 1984 alone, [[William Gibson (novelist)|William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'', [[Kim Stanley Robinson]]'s ''[[Three Californias Trilogy|The Wild Shore]]'', [[Lucius Shepard]]'s ''Green Eyes'', and [[Michael Swanwick]]'s ''In the Drift''. All were first novels by authors now regarded as major figures in the sf genre.
Other prominent sf publishing figures who have worked at Ace include [[Tom Doherty]], who left to start [[Tor Books]], and [[Jim Baen]], who left to work at Tor and who eventually founded [[Baen Books]]. Writers who have worked at Ace include [[Frederik Pohl]], [[Ellen Kushner]], and [[Laura Anne Gilman]].
In 1996, [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]] acquired the Putnam Berkley Group, and has retained Ace as their sf imprint. Ace's 2006 list includes [[Julian May]], [[Patricia A. McKillip|Patricia McKillip]], and [[Sharon Shinn]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week February 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books02b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week March 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books03b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New in Paperback: April 2006 | url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/NewInPaperback04.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>, with books from writers such as [[Alastair Reynolds]], [[Charles Stross]], [[Jack McDevitt]] and [[Joe Haldeman]] planned for the remainder of the year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: Forthcoming Books| url=http://locusmag.com/ForthcomingBooks.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>

==Ace Books titles== Ace titles are frequently collected, both for their covers and for their affiliation with individual genres. Many individual titles are now highly sought after. Much of [[Philip K. Dick]]'s early work appeared in Ace editions, and is now difficult to find in good condition. Among the rarest Ace titles are: * [[William Burroughs]] (as William Lee) ''Junkie'' (1955, D-015, bound with Maurice Helbrand's ''Narcotic Agent'')<ref>Near-fine copy priced at $1,000 located in second-hand bookstore {{cite web | url = http://www.heritagebookshop.com/ | title = Heritage Book Shop, Inc. | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> * [[Harlan Ellison]] ''The Deadly Streets'' (1958, D-312)<ref>Fine copy priced at $349.95 located in second-hand bookstore Wild Hills Books, Florida, via {{cite web | url = http://www.alibris.com/ | title = Alibris | accessdate = 14 August | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
The doubles format in itself has proved particularly attractive to collectors, with specialist reference works created for both the mystery and sf books, listing only the doubles. Several of these works are listed at the end of the reference section below. The following articles provide lists of all the Ace titles, organized by genre and by format (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'' vs. normal format).

=== Serial numbers === Ace titles have had two main types of serial numbers: letter series, such as "D-31" and "H-77", and numeric, such as "10293" and "15697". The letters were used to indicate a price. The following is a list of series with their date ranges and prices.
* D-series—35¢, 1952 to 1965. * S-series—25¢, 1954 to 1958. * T-series—40¢. This series is listed in Tuck's Encyclopedia,<ref>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 3| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1982 | pages = 715|id=ISBN 0-911682-26-0}}</ref> but he gives no examples in his index and there are none cited in other bibliographic sources. This series may therefore not exist. * F-series—40¢, 1960 to 1967. * M-series—45¢, 1964 to 1966. * G-series—50¢, 1958 to 1960 (D/S/G series); 1964 to 1968 (later series). * K-series—50¢, 1959 to 1968. * H-series—60¢, 1965 or 1966 to 1968. * A-series—75¢, 1965 to 1968. * N-series—95¢, 1965 to 1968.
The first series of Ace books began in 1952 with D-01, a western in ''dos-à-dos'' format: [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'' backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo''. That series continued until D-599, [[Patricia Libby]]'s ''Winged Victory for Nurse Kerry'', but the series also included several G and S serial numbers, depending on the price. The D and S did not indicate "Double" (i.e., ''dos-à-dos'') or "Single"; there are D-series titles that are not ''dos-à-dos'', although none of the ''dos-à-dos'' titles have an S serial number.
Towards the end of this initial series, the F series began (at a new price), and thereafter there were always several different letter series in publication simultaneously. The D and S prefixes did not appear again after the first series, but the G prefix acquired its own series starting with G-501. Hence the eight earlier G-series titles can be considered part of a different series to the G-series proper. All series after the first kept independent numbering systems, starting at 1 or 101.
In January 1969, Ace switched to a numeric coding system. The code depended on the title of the book: specifically, on the first significant word in the title. For example, [[Tom Purdom]]'s ''The Barons of Behavior'' was published by Ace in about 1972 as serial number 04760. The first letter of "Barons" is "B", so the code assigned is fairly early in the numeric range 00000 to 99999. This procedure for assigning numeric codes was in use at Ace at least into the early 1990s, and may still be in use today. For Ace Doubles, one of the titles was selected and used to determine what serial number would be used. For example, 11560 is the Ace Double ''The Communipaths'' by [[Suzette Haden Elgin]], backed with [[Louis Trimble]]'s ''The Noblest Experiment in the Galaxy''. The serial number here is derived from ''The Communipaths''; a serial number derived from the Trimble would have been about 58000.
For the later numeric series titles, the number is also part of the [[ISBN]]. To form the ISBN (if it exists) for one of these books, one prefixes to the serial number "0" (representing the English language/US), and "441" (Ace's publisher number). The last digit can then be calculated with an ISBN check digit calculator. For example, [[Christopher Stasheff]]'s ''Escape Velocity'' has serial number 21599; the ISBN is 0-441-21599-8.

'''Ace Books''' is the oldest active specialty [[publisher]] of [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] [[novel|novels]]. The company was founded in 1952 by [[A. A. Wyn|Aaron A. Wyn]], and began as a genre publisher, starting with [[mystery fiction|mysteries]] and [[western (genre)|westerns]]. It soon branched out into other genres, publishing its first science fiction ("sf") title in 1953; this was a successful innovation, and within a few years, sf titles outnumbered both mysteries and westerns. Other genres also made an appearance, including non-fiction, [[gothic]] novels, and [[romance novel|romances]].
Ace became well known for the ''[[dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'' binding format used for most of its early books, although it did not originate the format. Most of Ace's early titles were published in this format, and Ace continued to issue books in many genres, bound ''dos-à-dos'', until 1973. Ace books have proven attractive to collectors, and some rare titles now command prices of up to $1,000.
Ace, along with [[Ballantine Books]], was one of the leading sf paperback publishers for its first ten years in business. With the death of owner A. A. Wyn in 1967, however, Ace's fortunes began to decline. Two prominent editors, [[Donald A. Wollheim]] and [[Terry Carr]], left in 1971, and in 1972 Ace was sold to [[Grosset & Dunlap]]. Despite financial troubles, Ace had further successes, particularly with the various [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] series, for which Carr was the editor. Further [[mergers and acquisitions]] resulted in Ace becoming a part of [[Berkley Books]], and Ace is now a paperback [[imprint]] of [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]]. The editorial team at Ace also edits the [[Roc Books]] imprint, although the two imprints maintain a separate identity.<ref name=Morgan>{{cite web | url = http://www.sfcanada.ca/winter2005/johnmorganinterview.htm | title = SF Canada Article - "An Interview with Editor John Morgan" by Celu Amberstone| accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
==Company founding and the Ace Doubles concept==
[[Image:AceD-36ConanCover.jpg|thumb|200px|Ace Double D-36, [[Robert E. Howard]]'s ''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan]] the Conqueror''. The novel on the reverse side was [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Sword of Rhiannon''.]] [[Editor]] [[Donald A. Wollheim]] was working at [[Avon (publishers)|Avon Books]] in 1952, but intensely disliked his job. While looking for other work, he tried to persuade [[A. A. Wyn]] to found a new paperback publishing company. Wyn was already a well-established publisher of books and [[pulp magazine]]s under the name [[A. A. Wyn's Magazine Publishers]].<ref name=Tuck_Wyn>{{cite book | first=Donald H. | last=Tuck |authorlink= Donald H. Tuck| title=The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy: Volume 2| publisher=Advent: Publishers, Inc. | location=Chicago | year=1978 | pages = 471|id=ISBN 0-911682-22-8}}</ref> His magazines included ''Ace Mystery'' and ''Ace Sports'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.philsp.com/data/data002.html | title = Magazine Data File | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> and it is perhaps from these titles that Ace Books would draw its name. Wyn liked Wollheim's idea but delayed for several months; meanwhile, Wollheim was applying for other jobs, including assistant editor at [[Pyramid Books]]. Pyramid mistakenly called Wyn's wife Rose for a reference, thinking Wollheim had worked for her. When Rose told her husband that Wollheim was applying for another job, Wyn made up his mind: he hired Wollheim immediately as an editor.<ref name=Knight130>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight | authorlink= Damon Knight|title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 130}}</ref>
The first book published by Ace was a pair of mysteries bound ''[[Dos-à-dos binding|dos-à-dos]]'': [[Keith Vining]]'s ''Too Hot for Hell'', backed with [[Samuel W. Taylor]]'s ''The Grinning Gismo'', priced at 35 [[cent]]s, with serial number D-01. A ''dos-à-dos'' book has the two titles bound upside-down with respect to each other, so that there are two front covers and the two texts meet in the middle (sometimes with advertising pages in between). This format has been generally regarded as an innovation of Ace's; it was not, but Ace published hundreds of titles bound this way over the next twenty years, and became the best-known publisher of the format. Books by established authors were often bound with those by lesser-known writers, on the premise that this would help more-obscure authors gain popularity. The main drawback of the Doubles format was that the two books had to fit a fixed page length (usually totalling between 256 and 320 low-height pages), thus one or both novels would often be cut to fit. Despite the cover statement "Complete and Unabridged", books so-labeled were often cut significantly.<ref>{{cite book | last= Corrick| first= James A.| authorlink= James A. Corrick| title= Double Your Pleasure: the ACE SF Double| year= 1989 | publisher= Gryphon Books| location= New York| | pages= 11|id = ISBN 0-936071-13-3}}</ref>
The last Ace double in ''dos-à-dos'' format was [[Mack Reynolds]]' ''The Rival Rigelians'', bound with his ''Planetary Agent X'', released in September 1973. Although Ace later released volumes containing two novels, they were arranged conventionally rather than ''dos-à-dos''. It was not until 1978 that Ace finally stopped releasing Doubles. All told, Ace published nearly 650 Ace Doubles, more than 600 of which were in ''dos-à-dos'' format.
==1950s and 1960s: genre specialization==
[[Image:AceGenreGraph.png|thumb|400px|Books published by genre during Ace's first seventeen years. Science fiction overtook the other two main genres by the mid-1950s, and was by far the dominant genre published in the '60s.]] Ace's second title was a western (also ''dos-à-dos''): [[William Colt MacDonald]]'s ''Bad Man's Return'', bound with [[J. Edward Leithead]]'s ''Bloody Hoofs''. Mysteries and westerns alternated regularly for the first thirty titles, with a few books not in either genre, such as [[P. G. Wodehouse]]'s ''[[Quick Service]]'', bound with his ''[[The Code of the Woosters]]''. In 1953, [[A.E. van Vogt]]'s ''[[The World of Null-A]]'', bound with his ''The Universe Maker'', appeared; this was Ace's first science fiction title. Earlier in 1953, Ace had released [[Theodore S. Drachman]]'s ''Cry Plague!'', with a plot that could be regarded as sf, but the book it was bound with—[[Leslie Edgley]]'s ''The Judas Goat''—was not sf, so the van Vogt Double is generally regarded as Ace's first foray into science fiction. Another sf Ace Double followed later in 1953, and sf rapidly established itself, alongside westerns and mysteries, as an important part of Ace's business. By 1955, more sf titles were released each year than in either of the other two genres, and from 1961 onward, the sf titles outnumbered the mysteries and westerns combined.
Another first for Ace came immediately after the van Vogt Double: [[Dorothy Malone (writer)|Dorothy Malone]]'s ''Cookbook for Beginners'' was the first Ace book not in ''dos-à-dos'' format. Single novels began to appear frequently beginning in 1954, and were at first used primarily for books not in Ace's main three genres (though the occasional sf, mystery or western title did appear in single format). By the 1960s, however, this had changed, and the letter-series system apparently indicated the change: the F and M series singles were overwhelmingly science fiction, but singles in the original D/G/S series, and the K series singles, were mostly outside Ace's three genres.
By the late 1950s, Ace's output was approaching a hundred titles a year, still heavily dominated by the three main genres. Almost all the books were 35 cents, though some slim single volumes were 25 cents, and a handful were 50 cents. In the early '60s, rising costs finally forced an increase in the price of the books, and more and more books appeared at 40 cents, 45 cents and higher. A few fat volumes such as the 1967 paperback of [[Frank Herbert]]'s ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'' were priced at 95 cents. Other genres began to make a much more frequent appearance: scores of "nurse romances" appeared, beginning in 1960 with [[Joan Sargent]]'s ''Cruise Nurse'' bound with ''Calling Dr. Merriman'' by [[Margaret Howe]]. By the end of the decade, perhaps 70 more such titles had appeared, along with gothic novels, self-improvement books, "strange but true" books, and many others.
===Leader in science fiction===
With [[Ballantine Books]], Ace was the dominant science fiction paperback publisher in the 1950s and '60s. Other publishers followed their lead, catering to the increasing audience for sf, but none matched the influence of either company.<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 977}}</ref>
Market dominance was not only reflected in numbers of books published—Ace published the first novels of several noted science fiction authors during this period. They include: * [[Philip K. Dick]]'s ''[[Solar Lottery]]'' (1955, D-103, bound with [[Leigh Brackett]]'s ''The Big Jump''); * [[Gordon R. Dickson]]'s ''Alien from Arcturus'' (1956, D-139, bound with [[Nick Boddie Williams]]' ''The Atom Curtain''); * [[Samuel R. Delany]]'s ''The Jewels of Aptor'' (1962, F-173, bound with [[James White]]'s ''Second Ending''); * [[Ursula K. Le Guin]]'s ''[[Rocannon's World]]'' (1966, G-574, bound with [[Avram Davidson]]'s ''The Kar-Chee Reign''); * [[Roger Zelazny]]'s ''[[...And Call Me Conrad|This Immortal]]'' (1966, F-393); * [[R. A. Lafferty]]'s ''[[Past Master (novel)|Past Master]]'' (1968, H-54).
Ace published much early work of other prominent authors, including [[John Brunner (novelist)|John Brunner]], [[Thomas M. Disch]], and [[Robert Silverberg]].
==Mid-1960s to today== [[Image:AceRussChaosDiedCover.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Joanna Russ]]'s ''And Chaos Died'' (1970), from the first [[Ace Science Fiction Specials|Ace SF Special]] series. The cover is by [[Leo and Diane Dillon]].]]
In 1964, science fiction author [[Terry Carr]] joined the company, and, in 1968, he initiated the [[Ace Science Fiction Specials]] line, publishing critically-acclaimed original novels by such authors as [[Alexei Panshin]], [[R. A. Lafferty]], [[Joanna Russ]] and [[Ursula Le Guin]]. During the mid-to-late 1960s, Ace also obtained licenses to publish original novels based on several popular television series of the day, most notably some two-dozen ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' volumes and a trilogy based on ''[[The Prisoner]]''.
Carr and Wollheim also co-edited an annual ''Year's Best Science Fiction'' [[anthology]] series; and Carr also edited ''Universe'', a well-received original anthology series. ''Universe'' was initially published by Ace, although when Carr left Ace Books in 1971 the series moved elsewhere.
<!-- ==''Lord of the Rings'' controversy --> In 1965, Wollheim discovered a [[copyright]] loophole in the American edition of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. The [[Houghton Mifflin]] edition had been bound using pages printed in the [[United Kingdom]] for the [[Allen & Unwin|George Allen & Unwin]] edition, and as a result, U.S. copyright law (at that time) did not protect the text. Exploiting this loophole, Ace Books published the first-ever paperback edition of Tolkien's work, featuring cover art and hand-drawn title pages by [[Jack Gaughan]]. After considerable controversy and the release of a competitive authorized (and more complete) edition by Ballantine Books, Ace agreed to pay royalties to Tolkien and let its still-popular edition go out of print.<ref>{{cite web | author=Reynolds, Pat| year=2004| title=The Lord of the Rings: The Tale of a Text | url=http://www.tolkiensociety.com/tolkien/tale.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{ME-ref|letters|especially #270, #273 and #277}}</ref>
Wyn died in 1967,<ref name=Tuck_Wyn /> and the company grew financially overextended, failing to pay its authors reliably. Without money to pay the signing bonus, Wollheim was unwilling to send signed contracts to authors. On at least one occasion, a book without a valid contract went to the printer, and Wollheim later found out that the author, who was owed $3,000 by Ace, was reduced to picking fruit for a living.<ref name=Knight176>{{cite book | first=Damon | last=Knight |authorlink= Damon Knight| title=The Futurians | publisher=John Day | location=New York | year=1977 | pages = 176}}</ref>
Both Wollheim and Carr left Ace in 1971. Wollheim had made plans to launch a separate paperback house, and in cooperation with [[New American Library]],<ref name=Knight176 /> he proceeded to set up [[DAW Books]]. Carr became a freelance editor; both Carr and Wollheim went on to edit separate Year's Best volumes.
In 1972, Ace was acquired by [[Grosset & Dunlap]], and in 1982, Grosset & Dunlap was in turn acquired by [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]]. Ace was reputedly the only profitable element of the Grosset & Dunlap empire by this time.<ref name=chicon>{{cite web | author=Bloom, Jeremy| year=1999| title=Chicon 2000:Editor Guest of Honor: Jim Baen | work=An Interview with the Editor Guest of Honor, Jim Baen| url=http://www.chicon.org/gohs/baen.htm | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: History| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/history.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> Ace soon became the science fiction imprint of their parent company.<ref name=penguin-ace>{{cite web |title=Penguin Group (USA): About Us: Ace Books| url=http://us.penguingroup.com/static/html/aboutus/adult/ace.html | accessdate = 10 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Grosset & Dunlap operated an imprint called Ace Charter Books, which published mystery fiction such as reprints of the ''[[Simon Templar|The Saint]]'' series by [[Leslie Charteris]].
Carr returned to Ace Books in 1984 as a [[freelancer|freelance]] editor,<ref>{{cite book | editor= [[John Clute|Clute, John]] & [[Peter Nicholls|Nicholls, Peter]]| title= The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction| origdate= 1993| publisher= [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press, Inc.]]| location= New York| pages= 199}}</ref> launching a new series of Ace Specials devoted entirely to first novels. This series was even more successful than the first: it included, in 1984 alone, [[William Gibson (novelist)|William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'', [[Kim Stanley Robinson]]'s ''[[Three Californias Trilogy|The Wild Shore]]'', [[Lucius Shepard]]'s ''Green Eyes'', and [[Michael Swanwick]]'s ''In the Drift''. All were first novels by authors now regarded as major figures in the sf genre.
Other prominent sf publishing figures who have worked at Ace include [[Tom Doherty]], who left to start [[Tor Books]], and [[Jim Baen]], who left to work at Tor and who eventually founded [[Baen Books]]. Writers who have worked at Ace include [[Frederik Pohl]], [[Ellen Kushner]], and [[Laura Anne Gilman]].
In 1996, [[Penguin Group|Penguin Group (USA)]] acquired the Putnam Berkley Group, and has retained Ace as their sf imprint. Ace's 2006 list includes [[Julian May]], [[Patricia A. McKillip|Patricia McKillip]], and [[Sharon Shinn]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week February 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books02b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New Books, 2nd Week March 2006| url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/Books03b.html| accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: New in Paperback: April 2006 | url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Monitor/NewInPaperback04.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>, with books from writers such as [[Alastair Reynolds]], [[Charles Stross]], [[Jack McDevitt]] and [[Joe Haldeman]] planned for the remainder of the year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Locus Online: Forthcoming Books| url=http://locusmag.com/ForthcomingBooks.html | accessdate = 11 May | accessyear = 2006}}</ref>
